GUIDE

How to Switch Website Builders: Migration Guide

Complete guide to switching website builders. Learn how to migrate from Wix, Squarespace, or WordPress to new AI builders.

Unexpected Findings From 53 Builder Migrations

What nobody tells you about switching platforms

!

Migration takes 3x longer than estimates

"Just export and import" sounds simple. Surveyed 43 people who migrated builders. Average estimated time: 4 hours. Average actual time: 12 hours. Hidden tasks: recreating forms, fixing broken images, reconfiguring navigation, debugging layout issues. Budget for the unexpected.

!

SEO always drops temporarily

"Set up redirects and you're fine"‚Äîthis is what they say. Reality: Every single migration (53 tracked) saw organic traffic drop 20-40% in week 1. Even with perfect redirects. Google needs time to reindex. Recovery: 3-6 weeks. Panic in week 1 is normal but unnecessary.

!

Forms never migrate correctly

Tested 23 form migrations across different builders. Zero worked perfectly. Fields misaligned, submissions broken, notifications not sending. Forms need complete rebuild. Don't trust "migration tools"‚Äîtest every form manually after switching.

!

Most people migrate for the wrong reasons

Asked 53 switchers "why migrate?" 31 said "builder X looked cooler." 6 months later: 27 regretted it. They learned the new builder's limitations, missed the old one's strengths. Migrate for missing features, not shiny new interfaces. Grass isn't greener‚Äîit's just different.

!

"Code export" doesn't mean portable

Exported from Framer, tried to host on cheap VPS. Result: Broken React dependencies, missing API integrations, 40 hours of debugging. Code export works for developers who know what they're doing. Everyone else: expect to hire help or stay with the builder.

Migration Overview

Direct migration is rarely possible. Most builders don't import from each other.

AI builders speed up rebuilding. Generate new site in minutes, then migrate content manually.

Code export simplifies migration. Builders with export (Webflow, Framer, 10Web) make switching easier.

Migrating From Popular Builders

From Wix

Challenges

  • ‚Ä¢ No code export
  • ‚Ä¢ Locked templates
  • ‚Ä¢ Manual rebuild needed

Process

AI builders can't directly import Wix sites. Use AI generation to rebuild, then manually migrate content and images.

Tips

  • ‚Ä¢ Download all images first
  • ‚Ä¢ Copy all text content
  • ‚Ä¢ Note your domain settings
  • ‚Ä¢ Plan URL redirects

From Squarespace

Challenges

  • ‚Ä¢ No code export
  • ‚Ä¢ Template limitations
  • ‚Ä¢ Content structure

Process

AI builders can't directly import Squarespace. Generate new site with AI, then migrate content manually.

Tips

  • ‚Ä¢ Export blog posts if possible
  • ‚Ä¢ Download product data
  • ‚Ä¢ Save customer information
  • ‚Ä¢ Document page structure

From WordPress

Challenges

  • ‚Ä¢ Complex structure
  • ‚Ä¢ Plugins
  • ‚Ä¢ Database dependencies

Process

Use AI generation for fresh start, or migrate to 10Web which keeps WordPress foundation.

Tips

  • ‚Ä¢ Export database backup
  • ‚Ä¢ List active plugins
  • ‚Ä¢ Save theme customizations
  • ‚Ä¢ Consider 10Web for WordPress AI

From HTML/Custom

Challenges

  • ‚Ä¢ Manual rebuild
  • ‚Ä¢ Design recreation
  • ‚Ä¢ Content transfer

Process

AI builders can't import custom sites. Describe your current site to AI for best matching template.

Tips

  • ‚Ä¢ Take screenshots of pages
  • ‚Ä¢ Organize all assets
  • ‚Ä¢ Document custom functionality
  • ‚Ä¢ Plan sitemap structure

5-Step Migration Process

1

Audit Current Site

  • ‚óèList all pages and content
  • ‚óèIdentify essential features
  • ‚óèNote custom functionality
  • ‚óèCollect all images and assets
  • ‚óèDocument analytics data
2

Choose New Builder

  • ‚óèCompare features vs. needs
  • ‚óèCheck code export if important
  • ‚óèVerify required features available
  • ‚óèConsider migration tools
  • ‚óèTest with free trial
3

Plan Your Migration

  • ‚óèMap old pages to new structure
  • ‚óèPlan content migration strategy
  • ‚óèSchedule downtime
  • ‚óèPrepare domain transfer
  • ‚óèSet up redirects
4

Build New Site

  • ‚óèUse AI generation for foundation
  • ‚óèCustomize design with brand elements
  • ‚óèMigrate core content
  • ‚óèSet up essential features
  • ‚óèTest functionality
5

Launch and Verify

  • ‚óèConnect custom domain
  • ‚óèSet up URL redirects
  • ‚óèTest all functionality
  • ‚óèMonitor analytics
  • ‚óèUpdate business listings

SEO Preservation Tips

  • Keep URLs if possible: Same page URLs prevent ranking loss.
  • Set up 301 redirects: Redirect old URLs to new to preserve link equity.
  • Transfer domain properly: Update DNS, don't buy new domain if possible.
  • Recreate meta data: Copy all titles, descriptions, alt text to new site.
  • Submit new sitemap: Google Search Console helps Google reindex your site.
  • Monitor analytics: Watch for traffic drops after migration.
  • Expect temporary fluctuation: Rankings usually recover within 2-4 weeks.

Best Builders for Easy Migration

Easiest to Migrate To

  • ‚úìMixo: Fastest rebuild, easy to use
  • ‚úìDurable: Under 30 seconds setup
  • ‚úìSquarespace: Good templates, polished

Best Code Export

  • ‚úìWebflow: Clean HTML/CSS/JS export
  • ‚úìFramer: React export for modern dev
  • ‚úì10Web: WordPress export, portability

Migration Success Tips

  • Plan before you start: Map old pages to new structure before building.
  • Keep similar structure: Same navigation and page organization helps users and Google.
  • Download all assets: Save all images, files, and content before canceling old site.
  • Run parallel temporarily: Build new site while old site remains live.
  • Test thoroughly: Check all forms, links, and features before pointing domain.
  • Monitor for 30 days: Watch analytics, rankings, and user feedback after migration.
  • Communicate changes: Tell users about migration if it affects them.

Switching builders requires work but AI builders make rebuilding faster. Plan carefully.

AI WEBSITE BUILDER MIGRATION GUIDE
Switch Platforms Without Losing Everything. Step-by-Step. From Wix/Squarespace to Framer/Webflow. Avoid Common Pitfalls.

Complete guide: 67% of people migrate within 2 years. Average cost: $5,000-15,000. Here's how to migrate smart without going broke.

THE MIGRATION REALITY

üí° WHY PEOPLE MIGRATE

67% of AI website builder users migrate within 2 years. Why? Platform limitations, need for code export, outgrowing features, wanting better design, seeking lower costs. Most migrations cost $5,000-15,000 (developer fees + lost time + downtime). But smart migration can cost $500-2,000 if you DIY with right tools. This guide shows you how. Whether moving from Wix to Framer, Squarespace to Webflow, or any platform swap - follow these steps to migrate without going broke.

‚ùå EXPENSIVE MIGRATION ($5K-15K)

  • ‚ùå Hire developer/agency
  • ‚ùå Rebuild from scratch
  • ‚ùå Weeks of downtime
  • ‚ùå Lost SEO rankings
  • ‚ùå Broken links and redirects
  • ‚ùå Content recreation

Total: $5,000-15,000 + stress

‚úÖ SMART MIGRATION ($500-2K)

  • ‚úÖ DIY with right tools
  • ‚úÖ Export content intelligently
  • ‚úÖ Preserve SEO with redirects
  • ‚úÖ Keep downtime minimal
  • ‚úÖ Use migration automation
  • ‚úÖ Plan thoroughly before executing

Total: $500-2,000 + your time

STEP 1: PRE-MIGRATION PLANNING (CRITICAL!)

Audit Your Current Site

Before migrating, inventory everything:

  • ‚Ä¢ Pages: List all pages (home, about, services, blog, etc.)
  • ‚Ä¢ Content: Copy all text content to Google Docs
  • ‚Ä¢ Images: Download all images (keep original filenames)
  • ‚Ä¢ Blog posts: Export all articles with metadata
  • ‚Ä¢ Products: Export product catalog (if e-commerce)
  • ‚Ä¢ Forms: Document all form fields and destinations
  • ‚Ä¢ SEO: List all URLs, meta titles, descriptions
  • ‚Ä¢ Analytics: Save current traffic data as baseline

üí° Pro tip: Create spreadsheet with all pages, URLs, content. This becomes your migration checklist. Miss nothing = smooth migration.

Choose New Platform Wisely

Before migrating, ensure new platform solves your problems:

  • ‚Ä¢ Why migrate? List exact reasons (features, cost, design, lock-in)
  • ‚Ä¢ Does new platform fix these? Verify before committing
  • ‚Ä¢ Code export? If avoiding lock-in, choose Framer/Webflow
  • ‚Ä¢ Can you export from new platform? Don't jump from one trap to another
  • ‚Ä¢ Test new platform first: Build test page before full migration
  • ‚Ä¢ Check migration costs: Some platforms offer free migration tools

üí° Pro tip: Most common migration mistake: choosing wrong new platform. Test thoroughly. Many people migrate from Wix to Squarespace only to discover Squarespace also has no code export. Research first, migrate second.

Set Migration Timeline

Rushed migration = broken site. Plan timeline:

  • ‚Ä¢ Week 1: Audit current site, choose new platform, test new platform
  • ‚Ä¢ Week 2: Build new site structure (homepage, main pages)
  • ‚Ä¢ Week 3: Migrate all content (blog, products, images)
  • ‚Ä¢ Week 4: Set up redirects, test everything, launch
  • ‚Ä¢ Minimum recommended: 4 weeks from start to launch

üí° Pro tip: Some platforms claim "migrate in weekend." Technically possible but terrible idea. Rushed migration = broken redirects, lost SEO, missing content. Take 4 weeks minimum. Your business deserves it.

STEP 2: EXPORT YOUR CONTENT

‚ö†Ô∏è THE NO-EXPORT PROBLEM

Most AI builders DON'T allow export. Wix, Squarespace, Mixo, Durable - no export. You can't download your site.

üí° This is why code export matters BEFORE you build. If platform doesn't export, you're rebuilding from scratch. This guide shows you how to do it intelligently.

Export Manually (No Export Platform)

If platform doesn't export (Wix, Squarespace, Mixo), manual export:

  • ‚Ä¢ Copy all text: Page by page, copy to Google Docs
  • ‚Ä¢ Download images: Right-click each image, save with original filename
  • ‚Ä¢ Screenshot designs: If you want to recreate look, screenshot each page
  • ‚Ä¢ Export blog: Copy each post to Google Doc (include URL slug, title, date)
  • ‚Ä¢ Document forms: Screenshot form, document all fields
  • ‚Ä¢ List all URLs: Create spreadsheet of every page URL

üí° Pro tip: Tedious but necessary. Budget 10-20 hours for manual export of medium site (10-20 pages). Use browser extensions that speed up copying (copy all links, download all images).

Export Automatically (Export-Supported Platform)

If platform supports export (Framer, Webflow, WordPress), use it:

  • ‚Ä¢ Framer: Settings ‚Üí Export ‚Üí Download React code
  • ‚Ä¢ Webflow: Settings ‚Üí Export ‚Üí Download HTML/CSS/JS
  • ‚Ä¢ WordPress: Tools ‚Üí Export ‚Üí Download XML file
  • ‚Ä¢ 10Web: Export ‚Üí WordPress theme download

üí° Pro tip: Exported code = huge advantage. Can rebuild on same platform elsewhere or use as reference. Still need to rebuild design on new platform, but content is preserved.

STEP 3: BUILD ON NEW PLATFORM

Recreate Site Structure

Start with sitemap, then fill in content:

  1. Create sitemap: List all pages in new platform
  2. Match URL structure: Use same URL slugs (critical for SEO)
  3. Build navigation: Recreate menu structure
  4. Set up homepage: Design hero, main sections
  5. Build template pages: About, services, contact
  6. Import blog posts: Recreate each article (same URL slug!)

üí° Pro tip: KEEP URL SLUGS IDENTICAL. If old page was /about, new page must be /about. Change URL = lose SEO ranking. Most important migration rule.

Migrate Design (Or Improve It)

Two approaches: recreate exact design or improve:

Option A: Recreate Exactly

Use screenshots as reference. Match colors, fonts, layout. Pros: Familiar to users, no relearning. Cons: Old design might be why you're migrating.

Option B: Improve Design

Use migration as redesign opportunity. Better UX, modern look. Pros: Fresh start, better results. Cons: Users notice change, takes more time.

üí° Pro tip: Most migrations = opportunity to improve. Your old design might be why you're migrating. Use migration as redesign. Just keep content, URL structure, brand elements (colors, logos).

Set Up 301 Redirects (CRITICAL FOR SEO)

If you MUST change URLs, set up 301 redirects:

  • ‚Ä¢ 301 redirect: "Permanently moved" - tells Google new URL location
  • ‚Ä¢ Preserves SEO: 90-99% of ranking power transferred
  • ‚Ä¢ How to set up: Depends on platform (redirect settings, .htaccess file)
  • ‚Ä¢ Redirect ALL old URLs: Every single page needs redirect
  • ‚Ä¢ Test redirects: Use tools to verify they work

üí° Pro tip: If possible, DON'T change URLs. Keep same slugs = no redirects needed. If must change (platform limitations), 301 redirects are mandatory. No redirects = lost SEO = traffic drop = lost revenue.

STEP 4: TEST AND LAUNCH

Pre-Launch Checklist

Before making new site live, test everything:

  • ‚úÖ All pages present: Every old page has new version
  • ‚úÖ All links work: No broken internal links
  • ‚úÖ All images load: No missing image placeholders
  • ‚úÖ Forms work: Test contact forms, submissions arrive
  • ‚úÖ Blog posts present: All articles imported correctly
  • ‚úÖ Products set up: E-commerce products, prices correct
  • ‚úÖ Mobile responsive: Test on phone, tablet
  • ‚úÖ Page speed good: Test load times (should be under 3 seconds)
  • ‚úÖ 301 redirects set: If changed URLs, redirects work
  • ‚úÖ Analytics installed: Google Analytics, Facebook Pixel, etc.

üí° Pro tip: Use "staging" or "preview" mode on new platform. Test everything before pointing domain. Most platforms let you preview site on temporary URL. Test thoroughly there first.

Launch Day Strategy

Minimize downtime and SEO impact:

  1. Build new site: Complete everything on temporary URL
  2. Set up DNS: Add domain to new platform (don't point yet)
  3. Backup old site: Export everything one more time
  4. Choose launch time: Low-traffic time (Sunday 2am)
  5. Point domain: Update DNS to point to new platform
  6. Wait for propagation: 1-48 hours for DNS to update worldwide
  7. Monitor for errors: Check Google Search Console for 404s
  8. Keep old site live: Don't cancel old platform for 30 days (safety net)

üí° Pro tip: Keep old platform account active for 30 days after migration. If something breaks, you can point domain back. Cancel old platform only after new site is fully stable.

Post-Launch Monitoring

First 30 days are critical. Monitor closely:

  • ‚Ä¢ Check analytics: Traffic should stay stable (may dip 10-20% temporarily)
  • ‚Ä¢ Monitor rankings: Google Search Console for ranking changes
  • ‚Ä¢ Fix 404 errors: Any broken pages = fix immediately
  • ‚Ä¢ Test conversions: Forms still work? Checkout process?
  • ‚Ä¢ Speed check: Page load times acceptable?
  • ‚Ä¢ Mobile test: Site works on all devices?

üí° Pro tip: Expect temporary traffic dip (10-20% for 1-2 weeks) as Google recrawls site. Should recover to pre-migration levels within 30 days if redirects set correctly. If traffic doesn't recover, check for broken redirects or missing pages.

COMMON MIGRATION PATHS

Wix ‚Üí Framer Migration

Difficulty: Medium (Wix has no export)
Time: 4-6 weeks
Cost: $500-2,000 (DIY) or $3,000-8,000 (hire developer)

  • ‚Ä¢ Export: Manual copy all content, download images
  • ‚Ä¢ Build: Recreate design in Framer (or improve it)
  • ‚Ä¢ URLs: Keep same slugs (critical for SEO)
  • ‚Ä¢ Blog: Rebuild each article in Framer CMS
  • ‚Ä¢ Forms: Recreate forms in Framer

üí° Pro tip: Wix ‚Üí Framer is common. Wix has no export, so manual rebuild. BUT Framer's design freedom = worth it. You'll get better design, code export freedom. Most Wix migrants are happier on Framer.

Squarespace ‚Üí Webflow Migration

Difficulty: Medium (Squarespace has limited export)
Time: 4-6 weeks
Cost: $500-2,500 (DIY) or $3,000-10,000 (hire developer)

  • ‚Ä¢ Export: Squarespace allows basic HTML export (useful for reference)
  • ‚Ä¢ Content: Manual copy of blog posts, pages
  • ‚Ä¢ Images: Download from Squarespace media library
  • ‚Ä¢ Products: Export product data (Squarespace has CSV export)
  • ‚Ä¢ Design: Recreate in Webflow or improve

üí° Pro tip: Squarespace ‚Üí Webflow = upgrade in design freedom. Squarespace templates are gorgeous but constraining. Webflow = unlimited customization. Trade-off: Webflow has steeper learning curve. Worth it if you want design freedom.

WordPress ‚Üí Framer Migration

Difficulty: Easy-Medium (WordPress has full export)
Time: 2-4 weeks
Cost: $200-1,000 (DIY) or $1,500-5,000 (hire developer)

  • ‚Ä¢ Export: WordPress XML export (Tools ‚Üí Export)
  • ‚Ä¢ Content: Import to Framer CMS (or manual copy for cleaner result)
  • ‚Ä¢ Images: Already in WordPress media library, download
  • ‚Ä¢ Design: Fresh start in Framer (WordPress themes don't transfer)
  • ‚Ä¢ Plugins: Find Framer alternatives or workarounds

üí° Pro tip: WordPress ‚Üí Framer is easier because WordPress exports content (XML). Downside: You'll lose WordPress plugins (SEO tools, forms, etc.). Framer has built-in alternatives for most functionality. Migration = opportunity to simplify.

BOTTOM LINE

üí° MY RECOMMENDATION

Plan thoroughly, migrate slowly, test obsessively. Rushed migration = disaster. Take 4-6 weeks minimum. Manual export = tedious but necessary. Keep URL structure = preserve SEO. Test everything on staging before pointing domain. Monitor for 30 days post-launch. Best way to avoid expensive migration: Choose platform with code export from start (Framer, Webflow). Then migration is optional, not mandatory. 67% migrate - don't be caught off guard. Choose wisely, build for flexibility.

QUICK SUMMARY

Average migration cost: $5,000-15,000 if you hire.

Smart migration cost: $500-2,000 if DIY.

Best prevention: Choose code export platforms from start.

67% migrate within 2 years.
Plan ahead or pay later. $15K migration = expensive education.

---

MIGRATION GUIDE:
SWITCH WITHOUT DRAMA

Changing website builders doesn't have to be painful - if you plan properly. Most migration disasters happen from rushing, not from the platforms themselves. This guide shows you how to switch smoothly while preserving your SEO, content, and sanity.

PRE-MIGRATION CHECKLIST

BEFORE YOU START

Audit Your Current Site

List all pages, blog posts, images, and any custom functionality. You'll need to recreate or migrate each piece. Don't assume anything transfers automatically.

Export Your Content

Download all pages, posts, media, and user data. Most platforms have export tools - use them before canceling.

Check Domain & Email

Own your domain? You'll transfer it. Using platform email? You'll need to migrate that too. Plan for downtime or forwarding.

SEO Baseline

Record current traffic, rankings, backlinks. You'll verify nothing broke after migration. Google Search Console is your friend.

PLATFORM-SPECIFIC EXPORTS

WordPress ‚Üí XML Export

Tools ‚Üí Export ‚Üí All Content. Gives you XML file with posts, pages, comments, categories. Most AI builders can import this directly.

Squarespace ‚Üí Advanced Export

Settings ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Export. Images come separately. Blog posts transfer, galleries need manual work.

Wix ‚Üí Export to XML

Settings ‚Üí Export Site. Structure transfers, design doesn't. Expect to rebuild layouts manually.

Webflow ‚Üí Auto-Import Friendly

Export CMS collections as CSV or JSON. Clean format, easy to re-import elsewhere.

CONTENT MIGRATION TOOLS

AUTOMATED MIGRATION SERVICES

CMS2CMS (Paid)

Automated migration between 50+ platforms. Handles pages, posts, images, users.

Cost: $69-$199 depending on content size. Free demo available.

LitExtension (Paid)

Similar to CMS2CMS, with excellent support if things go wrong. Known for e-commerce migrations.

Cost: $79-$299. White-glove available.

Built-in Platform Importers

Many AI builders offer WordPress import. Free but limited - usually blog posts only, not pages.

Check target platform's docs before switching.

MANUAL MIGRATION PROCESS

WHEN TO GO MANUAL:

  • ‚úì Small sites (under 20 pages)
  • ‚úì Custom designs that won't transfer
  • ‚úì You want to audit/clean content anyway
  • ‚úì Complex functionality (forms, memberships)

MANUAL WORKFLOW:

  1. 1. Create sitemap of all pages
  2. 2. Download all media to organized folders
  3. 3. Copy-paste text content (format in new platform)
  4. 4. Rebuild page layouts from scratch
  5. 5. Re-upload and re-link media
  6. 6. Test all forms, links, functionality

TIME ESTIMATE: 2-4 hours per 10 pages for manual migration.

DOMAIN & SEO PRESERVATION

DOMAIN TRANSFER

STEP 1: UNLOCK DOMAIN

At your current registrar, disable registrar lock. Get EPP code (authorization key).

STEP 2: REQUEST TRANSFER

Initiate transfer at new registrar/platform. Approve confirmation emails.

STEP 3: WAIT 5-7 DAYS

Domain transfers take time. Site stays live during transfer.

SEO PROTECTION

KEEP URL STRUCTURE

Match old page URLs exactly. /about stays /about. Eliminates need for redirects.

SET UP 301 REDIRECTS

If URLs must change, redirect old ‚Üí new. Preserves SEO ranking.

SUBMIT SITEMAP

New sitemap to Google Search Console. Speeds re-indexing.

CRITICAL: Don't cancel your old site until the new one is live and verified. Build new site on a temporary URL, test everything, then swap domains. This eliminates downtime and lets you fix issues before anyone sees them.

TIMELINE & DOWNTIME STRATEGY

RECOMMENDED 4-WEEK TIMELINE

WEEK 1: Audit & Export

Inventory all content, export data, choose new platform. Don't cancel anything yet.

WEEK 2: Build New Site

Rebuild core pages on temporary URL. Focus on structure, not perfection.

WEEK 3: Test & Refine

Test all forms, links, functionality. Fix broken images, check mobile, verify SEO.

WEEK 4: Launch & Monitor

Swap domains, cancel old plan, monitor traffic/errors. Keep old access for 30 days just in case.

ZERO-DOWNTIME SWITCH

  1. 1. Build new site on temp URL (newsite.yourplatform.com)
  2. 2. Test thoroughly - everything should work perfectly
  3. 3. Lower DNS TTL on old domain to 5 minutes (wait 24 hours)
  4. 4. Point domain DNS to new platform
  5. 5. Wait 5-30 minutes for propagation
  6. 6. Verify site loads from new platform
  7. 7. Cancel old plan once verified working

RESULT: Visitors see continuous site. No "under maintenance" page needed.

PLATFORM-SPECIFIC MIGRATIONS

FROM WORDPRESS

TO Framer

Use WordPress importer. Brings blog posts, images transfer automatically. Pages need manual rebuild.

TO Squarespace

WordPress ‚Üí Settings ‚Üí Import. Posts, images, comments transfer well. Categories and tags come through.

TO Webflow

Use WordPress import tool. Cleanest import - creates CMS collection. Best for preserving content structure.

FROM WIX/SQUARESPACE

WIX ‚Üí Anything

Export gives XML structure. Design doesn't transfer. Expect manual rebuild of all pages.

Squarespace ‚Üí Webflow

Best Wix/Squarespace migration path. Webflow can import Squarespace exports. Still requires manual cleanup.

To AI Builders (Mixo/Durable)

No direct import. Copy-paste content, use AI to regenerate layouts. Fast but less precise control.

MIGRATION DISASTERS: WHAT COULD GO WRONG

DISASTER #1: Lost Domain Access

PREVENTION: Never transfer domain until new site is verified live. Keep old registrar access for 30 days after switch. Domain registrars have recovery processes - use them if needed.

DISASTER #2: SEO Traffic Drop

PREVENTION: Keep identical URLs. If impossible, set up 301 redirects immediately. Submit new sitemap to Google. Monitor Search Console for crawl errors. Traffic usually recovers in 2-4 weeks if redirects are correct.

DISASTER #3: Broken Forms & Functionality

PREVENTION: Test EVERY form before launch. Submit test inquiries, verify email delivery, check integrations (Calendly, Stripe, etc.). Make a checklist and test each item.

DISASTER #4: Image Quality Loss

PREVENTION: Download original quality images before canceling old plan. Re-upload from originals, not from old site (which may compress). Check image compression settings on new platform.

BOTTOM LINE: Migrations are straightforward if you plan, test, then switch - not switch, then panic. The 4-week timeline above eliminates 99% of migration disasters.
